Home / How do you actually stick to time blocking?
27

How do you actually stick to time blocking?

I can plan a week of time blocks but by Wednesday it’s chaos. Meetings slip, tasks spill over. What’s a realistic way to time‑block without it becoming a guilt machine? Tools/process welcome.

productivity habits planning
Share Share on X Share on Facebook Share on LinkedIn Copied!
Nina
August 5, 2025 at 02:00 AM

9 Answers

Top Answer
33

Weekly cadence: - Friday: Plan next week; cap at 60% load. - Daily: Move tasks into blocks in the morning. - Noon: 10‑min replanning. - Evening: Mark what slipped; schedule a buffer. Hard rule: never “borrow” from sleep or workouts to pay calendar debt.

Grace
August 6, 2025 at 10:08 PM
19

Shrink the unit. If you can’t honor 2‑hour blocks, try 25/5 Pomodoros inside a loose block. Blocks give direction; the timer gives momentum.

Kate
August 5, 2025 at 03:33 AM
15

Add buffer blocks. I hold 2 × 30‑min overflow slots daily. Without buffers, one slip wrecks the whole plan.

Lee F
August 7, 2025 at 10:01 PM
11

Don’t over‑specify. Label a block “Deep work: project A” instead of “Write section 2.3.1”. Too granular → brittle.

Maria
August 8, 2025 at 04:35 PM
8

Schedule your work energy, not your time. My brain’s best 9–12 → hard tasks. Afternoons → meetings and shallow tasks. Sounds obvious; changed everything.

Tom
August 7, 2025 at 10:02 AM
6

Tooling: any calendar + a task app with Today view. Fancy apps won’t fix overcommitting.

Alex
3,200 reputation
August 6, 2025 at 06:50 AM
5

Audit your week first: where did blocks break? Causes: meetings, unclear scope, interruptions. Fix the cause before you redraw the calendar.

Jessica
2,800 reputation
August 9, 2025 at 01:31 PM
4

Interruptions? Use a visible “focus on” status. People ping less when your status says “heads down – reviewing PRD until 11:30”.

Ryan
2,400 reputation
August 9, 2025 at 04:10 PM
3

Time blocking works only if you protect it. Close Slack. Seriously.

John
1,500 reputation
August 9, 2025 at 06:00 AM
